lines.text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA

spans.text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA

lines.text: About this series: The climate crisis is intensifying humanitarian emergencies around the world and

spans.text: About this series: The climate crisis is intensifying humanitarian emergencies around the world and

lines.text: humanitarians are increasingly having to incorporate climate data and forecasts into their analysis

spans.text: humanitarians are increasingly having to incorporate climate data and forecasts into their analysis

lines.text: and planning. This guidance series has been developed to help humanitarians to access, analyze and

spans.text: and planning. This guidance series has been developed to help humanitarians to access, analyze and

lines.text: interpret common types of climate and weather data, and to provide a common language for working

spans.text: interpret common types of climate and weather data, and to provide a common language for working

lines.text: with meteorological and hydrological services.

spans.text: with meteorological and hydrological services.

lines.text: Key takeaways

spans.text: Key takeaways

lines.text: • Observational rainfall data such as CHIRPS or ARC2 captures how much rain has fallen over a

spans.text: •	 Observational rainfall data such as CHIRPS or ARC2 captures how much rain has fallen over a

lines.text: defined period of time.

spans.text: defined period of time.

lines.text: • The rainfall is measured at weather stations or estimated through satellite or radar imagery.

spans.text: •	 The rainfall is measured at weather stations or estimated through satellite or radar imagery.

lines.text: • The data can be presented as the total amount of rainfall observed over the period of time,

spans.text: •	 The data can be presented as the total amount of rainfall observed over the period of time,

lines.text: or as below, at or above normal conditions.

spans.text: or as below, at or above normal conditions.

lines.text: • Datasets that combine station data and satellite or radar imagery are the recommended

spans.text: •	 Datasets that combine station data and satellite or radar imagery are the recommended

lines.text: source of data for humanitarian purposes.

spans.text: source of data for humanitarian purposes.

lines.text: • Observational rainfall data can be analyzed to answer a range of questions, such as:

spans.text: •	 Observational rainfall data can be analyzed to answer a range of questions, such as:

lines.text: • What areas are currently affected by drought, and how severely?

spans.text: •	 What areas are currently affected by drought, and how severely?

lines.text: • What was the duration of the longest dry spell during the past rainy season?

spans.text: •	 What was the duration of the longest dry spell during the past rainy season?

lines.text: • How many days of heavy rainfall were there in the week leading up to the floods?

spans.text: •	 How many days of heavy rainfall were there in the week leading up to the floods?

lines.text: • Which area received the most rain last month?

spans.text: •	 Which area received the most rain last month?

lines.text: • How often does an area experience dry spells?

spans.text: •	 How often does an area experience dry spells?

lines.text: • How does this year’s rainfall compare to previous years?

spans.text: •	 How does this year’s rainfall compare to previous years?

lines.text: What is observational rainfall data?

spans.text: What is observational rainfall data?

lines.text: Observational rainfall data captures how much rain fell over a defined period of time,

spans.text: Observational rainfall data captures how much rain fell over a defined period of time,

lines.text: ranging from an hour to a day. This data can then be used to calculate the total rainfall for

spans.text: ranging from an hour to a day. This data can then be used to calculate the total rainfall for

lines.text: different time periods, such as 5 days ( pentad ), 10 days ( dekad ), a week, a month or a season.

lines.text: Observational precipitation data can be presented in various formats, each providing unique

spans.text: Observational precipitation data can be presented in various formats, each providing unique

lines.text: insights into precipitation patterns. The most common representation is through absolute

spans.text: insights into precipitation patterns. The most common representation is through absolute

lines.text: values, which reflect the actual amount of precipitation observed at a specific location and time,

spans.text: values, which reflect the actual amount of precipitation observed at a specific location and time,

lines.text: typically measured in millimeters. Precipitation averages, which are calculated from historical

spans.text: typically measured in millimeters. Precipitation averages, which are calculated from historical

lines.text: records over a period of typically at least 10 years, can be produced for a specific location,

spans.text: records over a period of typically at least 10 years, can be produced for a specific location,

lines.text: season, or year. A precipitation anomaly represents the deviation from the expected or average

spans.text: season, or year. A precipitation anomaly represents the deviation from the expected or average

lines.text: precipitation over a particular period, which can be expressed as a difference in millimeters

spans.text: precipitation over a particular period, which can be expressed as a difference in millimeters

lines.text: or as a percentage. The purpose of the analysis determines the most useful representation.

spans.text: or as a percentage. The purpose of the analysis determines the most useful representation.

lines.text: Common sources of observational rainfall data

spans.text: Common sources of observational rainfall data

lines.text: Among the many sources of data available, we introduce here two common sources of

spans.text: Among the many sources of data available, we introduce here two common sources of

lines.text: observational rainfall data, both of which combine station and satellite data: CHIRPS and ARC2.

spans.text: observational rainfall data, both of which combine station and satellite data: CHIRPS and ARC2.

lines.text: CHIRPS refers to the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data and is

spans.text: CHIRPS refers to the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data and is

lines.text: produced by scientists from the US Geological Survey and the Climate Hazards Center at the

spans.text: produced by scientists from the US Geological Survey and the Climate Hazards Center at the

lines.text: University of Santa Barbara. ARC2 refers to Africa Rainfall Climatology Version 2 and it is

spans.text: University of Santa Barbara.  ARC2 refers to Africa Rainfall Climatology Version 2 and it is

lines.text: produced by The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Climate Prediction Center

spans.text: produced by The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Climate Prediction Center

lines.text: for the Famine Early Warning System. You can access the data directly from these providers, or

spans.text: for the Famine Early Warning System. You can access the data directly from these providers, or

lines.text: Observational rainfall data cannot answer the following questions:

lines.text: Observational rainfall data is

spans.text: Observational rainfall data is

lines.text: referred to as observational because it describes what happened in the past. It does not tell

spans.text: referred to as observational because it describes what happened in the past. It does not tell

lines.text: you anything about future rainfall.

spans.text: you anything about future rainfall.

lines.text: • Is a severe flooding event about to occur? Are we going through a severe drought?

spans.text: •	 Is a severe flooding event about to occur? Are we going through a severe drought?

lines.text: Observational rainfall data does not provide sufficient information to inform you about the

spans.text: Observational rainfall data does not provide sufficient information to inform you about the

lines.text: risk of flooding in the near future or how severe a drought is likely to be. This is because

spans.text: risk of flooding in the near future or how severe a drought is likely to be. This is because

lines.text: floods and droughts are complex phenomena caused by several interacting factors and they

spans.text: floods and droughts are complex phenomena caused by several interacting factors and they

lines.text: cannot be explained exclusively by the amount of precipitation.

spans.text: cannot be explained exclusively by the amount of precipitation.

lines.text: • How much rainfall from a given period of time in the past was due to specific tropical

lines.text: storm or typhoon?

spans.text: storm or typhoon?

lines.text: It is hard to differentiate between the amount of rain caused by

spans.text: It is hard to differentiate between the amount of rain caused by

lines.text: average atmospheric conditions and the amount of rain induced by a specific atmospheric

spans.text: average atmospheric conditions and the amount of rain induced by a specific atmospheric

lines.text: phenomenon. As a result, using observational rainfall data alone, it is not possible to say how

spans.text: phenomenon. As a result, using observational rainfall data alone, it is not possible to say how

lines.text: much rainfall is due strictly to a tropical storm or typhoon. More data is needed to infer the

spans.text: much rainfall is due strictly to a tropical storm or typhoon. More data is needed to infer the

lines.text: origin of a heavy rainfall event.

lines.text: Common limitations with observations rainfall data

spans.text: Common limitations with observations rainfall data

lines.text: Once you have identified how you want to use the data, it is important to bear in mind some

spans.text: Once you have identified how you want to use the data, it is important to bear in mind some

lines.text: common limitations when conducting your analysis.

spans.text: common limitations when conducting your analysis.
